intro: Agoseris aurantiaca var. carnea, commonly known as the pink globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, pink to red petals that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has hairy, branching stems and heart-shaped leaves with a slightly serrated edge. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. The flowers attract pollinators like bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
